Statement_Language: Almanya'da din özgürlüğü yoktur. Burada da devlet vatandaşlarını bir sisteme zorluyor.
Reply:
Almanya'da din özgürlüğü konusunda yapılan bu değerlendirme, doğru olmayan bir bilgi içermektedir. Almanya'da, Anayasa'nın 4. maddesi uyarınca din ve vicdan özgürlüğü garanti altına alınmıştır. Buna göre, herkes dini inanç ve kanaatlerini serbestçe belirleyebilir ve bireyler, tek başlarına veya topluluk halinde, dini faaliyetlerde bulunma hakkına sahiptir.

Ancak, Almanya'da kilise vergisi (Kirchensteuer) gibi uygulamalar bulunmaktadır. Bu vergi, belirli bir dine mensup olan ve bu dini kurumların üyesi olan kişilerden alınır. Bu uygulama, devletin vatandaşları belirli bir sisteme zorladığı anlamına gelmez; çünkü kişiler, istedikleri takdirde dini cemaatlerden ayrılarak bu vergiyi ödemekten muaf olabilirler.

Sonuç olarak, Almanya'da din özgürlüğü mevcuttur ve devlet, vatandaşları belirli bir sisteme zorlamamaktadır. Vatandaşlar, dini inançlarını özgürce yaşayabilir ve dini kurumlara üyeliklerini kendi iradeleriyle belirleyebilirler.
EnglishTranslation:
This assessment of freedom of religion in Germany contains inaccurate information. In Germany, freedom of religion and conscience is guaranteed under Article 4 of the Constitution. Accordingly, everyone may freely manifest his or her religious beliefs and convictions and individuals have the right, individually or in community, to engage in religious activities.

However, in Germany, there is a church tax (Kirchensteuer). This tax is levied on people who belong to a particular religion and are members of these religious organizations. This practice does not mean that the state is forcing citizens into a particular system, as individuals can be exempted from paying this tax by leaving religious communities if they so choose.

In conclusion, freedom of religion exists in Germany and the state does not force citizens into a particular system. Citizens can freely practice their religious beliefs and determine their membership of religious institutions of their own free will.

Statement_English: There is no freedom of religion in Germany. Here, too, the state forces its citizens into a system.
Statement_Language: Daar is geen vryheid van godsdiens in Duitsland nie.Ook hier dwing die staat sy burgers in 'n stelsel.
Reply:
Die stelling dat "Daar is geen vryheid van godsdiens in Duitsland nie. Ook hier dwing die staat sy burgers in 'n stelsel" is nie heeltemal akkuraat nie. Duitsland het wel vryheid van godsdiens wat in die grondwet gewaarborg word. Artikel 4 van die Duitse Grondwet (Grundgesetz) waarborg die vryheid van geloof, gewete en godsdiens. Dit beteken dat individue die reg het om hulle godsdiens te beoefen of om geen godsdiens te beoefen nie.

Wat betref die stelling oor die staat wat burgers in 'n stelsel dwing, kan dit verwys na die kerkbelasting (Kirchensteuer) wat in Duitsland gehef word. Lidmate van sekere kerke, soos die Rooms-Katolieke Kerk en die Evangeliese Kerk, word belas om die kerk te ondersteun. Dit is egter belangrik om te noem dat deelname aan hierdie belastingstelsel vrywillig is in die sin dat 'n individu kan kies om uit die kerk te tree en sodoende die belasting te vermy.

Daarom, terwyl die stelsel van kerkbelasting dalk as dwang kan voel vir sommige, is dit nie 'n aanduiding dat daar geen vryheid van godsdiens in Duitsland is nie. Die vryheid om te glo of nie te glo nie, en om 'n godsdiens te beoefen of nie, word steeds gewaarborg.
EnglishTranslation:
The statement that "there is no freedom of religion in Germany. Here, too, the state is forcing its citizens into a system" is not entirely accurate. Germany does have freedom of religion guaranteed in the Constitution. Article 4 of the German Constitution (Grundsetz) guarantees the freedom of faith, conscience and religion. This means that individuals have the right to practice their religion or to practice no religion.

Regarding the statement about the state that forces citizens into a system, it can refer to the church tax (Kirchensteuer) charged in Germany. Members of certain churches, such as the Roman Catholic Church and the Evangelical Church, are burdened to support the church. However, it is important to mention that participation in this tax system is voluntary in the sense that an individual can choose to step out of the church and thus avoid the tax.

Therefore, while the system of church tax may feel as coercion for some, it is not an indication that there is no freedom of religion in Germany. The freedom to believe or not to believe, and practicing a religion or not, is still guaranteed.

Statement_English: There is no freedom of religion in Germany. Here, too, the state forces its citizens into a system.
Statement_Language: जर्मनी में धर्म की स्वतंत्रता नहीं है।यहाँ भी, राज्य अपने नागरिकों को एक प्रणाली में मजबूर करता है।
Reply:
जर्मनी में धर्म की स्वतंत्रता का मुद्दा जटिल है, लेकिन यह कहना सही नहीं होगा कि यहाँ धर्म की स्वतंत्रता नहीं है। जर्मनी का संविधान, जिसे ग्र Grundgesetz कहा जाता है, धारा 4 में धार्मिक और विश्वास की स्वतंत्रता की गारंटी देता है। इसका मतलब है कि प्रत्येक व्यक्ति को अपने धर्म या विश्वास का पालन करने का अधिकार है, और राज्य इसमें हस्तक्षेप नहीं कर सकता।

हालांकि, जर्मनी में एक विशेष प्रणाली है जिसे "धर्म कर" (Kirchensteuer) कहा जाता है, जो कुछ धार्मिक समुदायों के सदस्यों पर लागू होता है। यह कर स्वैच्छिक नहीं है, लेकिन इसे चुकाने का निर्णय व्यक्ति के धार्मिक समुदाय से जुड़े रहने या न रहने पर निर्भर करता है। यदि कोई व्यक्ति अपने धार्मिक समुदाय से अलग होना चाहता है, तो वह ऐसा कर सकता है और इस प्रकार धर्म कर से मुक्त हो सकता है।

इस प्रकार, जर्मनी में धर्म की स्वतंत्रता मौजूद है, लेकिन कुछ विशेष व्यवस्थाएँ हैं जो इसे प्रभावित कर सकती हैं। राज्य अपने नागरिकों को किसी विशेष धार्मिक प्रणाली में मजबूर नहीं करता, बल्कि उन्हें अपने धार्मिक विश्वासों के अनुसार चुनने की स्वतंत्रता देता है।
EnglishTranslation:
The issue of freedom of religion in Germany is complex, but it would not be right to say that there is no freedom of religion here. The Constitution of Germany, called Grundgesetz, guarantees freedom of religious and faith in Section 4. This means that every person has the right to follow his religion or faith, and the state cannot interfere with it.

However, there is a special system in Germany called "Dharma Tax", which applies to members of some religious communities. This tax is not voluntary, but the decision to repay it depends on the person's stay connected with the religious community or not. If a person wants to separate from his religious community, he can do so and thus religion can be free from tax.

Thus, freedom of religion exists in Germany, but there are some special arrangements that can affect it. The state does not force its citizens in a particular religious system, but gives them freedom to choose according to their religious beliefs.

Statement_English: There is no freedom of religion in Germany. Here, too, the state forces its citizens into a system.
Statement_Language: در آلمان هیچ آزادی دین وجود ندارد.در اینجا ، دولت نیز شهروندان خود را به یک سیستم وادار می کند.
Reply:
در پاسخ به این اظهارات باید گفت که این ادعاها با واقعیت‌های قانونی و اجتماعی آلمان همخوانی ندارند. در آلمان، آزادی دین و عقیده به طور کامل توسط قانون اساسی این کشور، یعنی قانون اساسی فدرال (Grundgesetz)، تضمین شده است. ماده 4 قانون اساسی آلمان به صراحت بیان می‌کند که "آزادی اعتقاد، وجدان و اعلام عقیده دینی و فلسفی تضمین شده است." 

همچنین، دولت آلمان شهروندان را به پیروی از هیچ سیستم خاصی مجبور نمی‌کند. در حالی که کلیساهای بزرگ مانند کلیسای کاتولیک و کلیسای پروتستان می‌توانند مالیات کلیسا (Kirchensteuer) را از اعضای خود دریافت کنند، پرداخت این مالیات کاملاً اختیاری است و افراد می‌توانند با خروج رسمی از کلیسا از پرداخت آن خودداری کنند.

بنابراین، ادعای عدم وجود آزادی دین و اجبار به پیروی از یک سیستم خاص در آلمان، با واقعیت‌های حقوقی و اجتماعی این کشور مطابقت ندارد.
EnglishTranslation:
In response to these statements, these claims are not in line with German legal and social realities. In Germany, the freedom of religion and belief is entirely guaranteed by the constitution of the country, the Federal Constitution (GRUNDGESTZ). Article 4 of the German Constitution explicitly states that "freedom of belief, conscience, and religious and philosophical beliefs are guaranteed." 

Also, the German government does not force citizens to follow any specific systems. While large churches such as the Catholic Church and the Protestant Church can receive the taxation of the church from their members, paying this tax is completely optional, and people can refuse to pay for it.

Therefore, the claim of lack of freedom of religion and compulsion to follow a particular system in Germany does not conform to its legal and social realities.
